title: NHL Skater Performance Analytics
text:
To add SHAP explanations for the Random Forest models in R, consider the following options:

‘iml’ package:

Use Predictor\(new(model, data = X_train) then Shapley\)new(…) or FeatureImp() for importance.

‘DALEX’ + ‘shapper’:

Use DALEX::explain() to wrap model+data, then shapper::shap() for per-observation explanations.

Python SHAP:

Export model predictions and features, run SHAP in Python (if you prefer), and import visualizations.


Example (DALEX): library(DALEX); explainer <- explain(rf_model, data = X_train, y = y_train); plot(importance(explainer))

title: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text: This section provides the detailed empirical analysis for Research Question 2, focusing on identifying players who demonstrate strong versatility on special teams. Rather than evaluating power-play (PP) and penalty-kill (PK) performance in isolation, we construct a unified metric—the Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)—that captures both offensive and defensive contributions.
crumbs: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)

3 3. Variable Selection and Validation

3.1 3.1 Required Columns
We use on-ice expected-goals metrics as proxies for special-teams performance.


Show / Hide Code
req_cols <- c(
  "player",
  "season",
  "OnIce_F_xGoals",
  "OnIce_A_xGoals",
  "toi"
)

missing_cols <- setdiff(req_cols, names(df))
if (length(missing_cols) > 0) {
  stop("Missing required columns: ", paste(missing_cols, collapse = ", "))
}
crumbs: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)

title: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
4 4. Constructing the STVS Metric

4.1 4.1 Power Play and Penalty Kill Proxies

PP Impact: On-ice expected goals for
PK Impact: Negative of on-ice expected goals against



Show / Hide Code
df <- df %>%
  mutate(
    pp_impact = as.numeric(OnIce_F_xGoals),
    pk_impact = -as.numeric(OnIce_A_xGoals)
  )




4.2 4.2 Standardization


Show / Hide Code
df <- df %>%
  mutate(
    pp_z = scale(pp_impact)[,1],
    pk_z = scale(pk_impact)[,1],
    STVS = pp_z + pk_z
  )

title: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
6 6. Predictive Modeling: Random Forest

6.1 6.1 Model Data Preparation


Show / Hide Code
rf_data <- df %>%
  select(STVS, pp_impact, pk_impact, toi) %>%
  drop_na()




6.2 6.2 Train Random Forest Model


Show / Hide Code
set.seed(515)
rf_model <- randomForest(
  STVS ~ pp_impact + pk_impact + toi,
  data = rf_data,
  importance = TRUE
)





6.3 6.3 Feature Importance


Show / Hide Code
varImpPlot(rf_model, main = "Random Forest Feature Importance for STVS")
crumbs: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)

title: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
7 7. Interpretation
The Random Forest model highlights both offensive (PP) and defensive (PK) components as critical drivers of special-teams versatility. Time on ice further moderates these effects, reflecting coaching trust and deployment context.
Players with high STVS scores are therefore those who consistently contribute under both numerical advantage and disadvantage.
crumbs: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)

title: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
8 8. Conclusion
RQ2 demonstrates that special-teams versatility can be quantified using a composite expected-goals-based metric. The STVS framework provides teams with a data-driven approach to identifying multi-role contributors and optimizing lineup decisions.
➡️ Next: rq3.qmd — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta
crumbs: RQ2 — Predicting Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)

title: Results & Discussion
text:
This section synthesizes findings from all three research questions and interprets the statistical and analytical results in the context of NHL skater performance.



Across all analyses, the results highlight that player value cannot be captured by a single metric such as total goals or ice time. Instead, advanced analytics such as expected goals, shift efficiency, and on-ice impact provide deeper insight into player contributions.




The first research question analyzed shift efficiency, defined as the difference between expected goals for and against per shift. Results show that:

Players with higher shift efficiency consistently demonstrated stronger two-way play.
High-efficiency players were not always those with the highest total ice time, indicating that quality of shifts matters more than quantity.
A diminishing returns pattern was observed, where increases in shifts beyond a threshold provided marginal efficiency gains.

This suggests that coaches may benefit from optimizing shift usage rather than maximizing player ice time.




The second research question examined player versatility in power play and penalty kill situations. Findings indicate that:

A subset of players contributes meaningfully in both special teams roles.
These versatile players tend to have higher overall expected goal impact.
Special teams effectiveness is strongly associated with team-level success metrics.

This highlights the importance of developing multi-role players who can adapt to different in-game situations.




The third research question focused on isolating player impact using on-ice versus off-ice metrics. Key results include:

Significant differences between on-ice and off-ice expected goal differentials for top-performing players.
Certain players demonstrated a strong positive impact even when controlling for team strength.
These impact deltas provide a more accurate representation of individual contribution than raw scoring statistics.

This reinforces the value of advanced on/off analytics in modern hockey evaluation.




The results of this analysis offer several practical implications:

Coaches can optimize line combinations using efficiency metrics.
Front offices can identify undervalued players using on/off impact measures.
Analysts can move beyond traditional statistics to more predictive performance indicators.





While informative, this study has several limitations:

The dataset does not account for player injuries or opposition strength.
Shift context (zone starts, matchups) is not fully captured.
The analysis is limited to a single season snapshot.

These limitations provide opportunities for further refinement.

title: RQ2 — Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
Which players are likely to demonstrate higher versatility on special teams, as measured by combined Power Play and Penalty Kill performance metrics?
Special teams play a decisive role in modern hockey outcomes. Players who can contribute effectively on both the power play (PP) and penalty kill (PK) offer significant strategic value to their teams. This research question introduces a composite metric—Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)—to quantify and analyze this dual impact.

title: RQ2 — Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
Which players are likely to demonstrate higher versatility on special teams, as measured by combined Power Play and Penalty Kill performance metrics?
Special teams play a decisive role in modern hockey outcomes. Players who can contribute effectively on both the power play (PP) and penalty kill (PK) offer significant strategic value to their teams. This research question introduces a composite metric—Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)—to quantify and analyze this dual impact.

title: RQ2 — Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
2 Conceptual Motivation
Power play effectiveness emphasizes offensive creation under advantage, while penalty killing emphasizes defensive suppression under disadvantage. Traditionally, these roles are evaluated independently. However, players capable of excelling in both situations provide lineup flexibility and roster efficiency.
The STVS metric integrates both dimensions into a single standardized score, enabling direct comparison across players with different usage patterns.

title: RQ2 — Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
3 Data and Variables
This analysis uses aggregated skater-level statistics from the NHL dataset. The following variables are central to RQ2:

On-ice expected goals for (PP proxy)
On-ice expected goals against (PK proxy)
Shifts and ice time (usage control)
Corsi and Fenwick-based possession metrics

Because the dataset is aggregated by situation, we rely on on-ice expected-goal measures as proxies for special-teams impact.

title: RQ2 — Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
4 Methodological Overview
To capture nonlinear interactions between offensive and defensive special-teams contributions, we propose a Random Forest regression model. This model is well-suited for:

Handling correlated predictors
Capturing threshold effects
Ranking variable importance

The outcome variable is the Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS), defined as:
[ = Z() + Z()]
where each component is standardized across players.

title: RQ2 — Special Teams Versatility Score (STVS)
text:
5 Expected Outputs
This research question will be answered using:

Distribution plots of STVS across players
Rankings of top versatile skaters
Feature-importance visualizations from the Random Forest model

Detailed construction of STVS, preprocessing steps, and visual analytics are presented in the next section.

title: About
text:
The dataset contains detailed NHL skater-level performance statistics across shifts, expected goals, Corsi metrics, Fenwick metrics, on-ice/off-ice performance, and special teams performance.
This dataset enables:

Micro-shift–level analytics

Expected goals modeling

Special teams evaluation

Advanced on/off impact estimation





xGoalsForAfterShifts
xGoalsAgainstAfterShifts
Corsi After Shifts
Fenwick After Shifts
Power Play metrics
Penalty Kill metrics
TOI (Time on Ice)
Shift counts
Player roles & positions





This dataset supports complex predictive analytics, such as:

Non-linear decay modeling (RQ1)
Composite scoring for special teams roles (RQ2)
Player impact segregation using on/off metrics (RQ3)

title: Conclusion & Future Work
text:
This project applied advanced statistical and visual analytics to evaluate NHL skater performance using shift-level and expected goal metrics. By integrating exploratory analysis, research-driven metrics, and interpretive insights, the study demonstrates the value of modern hockey analytics.



This project makes the following contributions:

Introduces shift efficiency as a meaningful performance indicator.
Highlights the importance of special teams versatility.
Demonstrates the effectiveness of on-ice vs off-ice impact analysis.
Provides a reproducible analytics workflow using R and Quarto.





From a data analytics perspective, this project demonstrates:

Appropriate variable selection and preprocessing
Use of exploratory and statistical techniques
Clear linkage between research questions and analytical outcomes
Effective communication of results through visualization and narrative

These align strongly with the learning objectives of STAT 515.




Future extensions of this project could include:

Multi-season trend analysis
Incorporation of player salary and contract value
Machine learning models for player impact prediction
Contextual variables such as zone starts and quality of competition
Interactive dashboards for team decision-makers





Advanced analytics are transforming how professional sports evaluate performance. By leveraging data-driven insights, teams can make smarter decisions that improve competitiveness and efficiency. This project demonstrates how statistical analytics can meaningfully contribute to sports decision-making.

title: descriptive
text:
This section summarizes the key descriptive statistics of the NHL skater performance dataset. We compute central tendencies, variability, distribution patterns, and identify any outliers that may influence later modeling steps.

# Load data
skaters <- read.csv("D:/GMU homeworks/STAT515/final proj/skaters.csv")

# Convert numeric-looking character columns
skaters_clean <- skaters %>%
  mutate(across(where(is.character), ~ suppressWarnings(as.numeric(.))))

# Summary statistics for numeric variables
numeric_summary <- skaters_clean %>%
  select(where(is.numeric)) %>%
  summarise(across(everything(),
                   list(
                     mean = ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                     median = ~ median(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                     sd = ~ sd(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                     min = ~ min(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                     max = ~ max(.x, na.rm = TRUE)
                   ),
                   .names = "{.col}_{.fn}"
  ))

Below we visualize distributions for important performance variables such as shifts, TOI, xGoalsForAfterShifts, and xGoalsAgainstAfterShifts.


Show / Hide Code
library(tidyr)


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.5.2


Show / Hide Code
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Desired variables
vars_to_plot <- c(
  "shifts",
  "toi",
  "xGoalsForAfterShifts",
  "xGoalsAgainstAfterShifts"
)

# Keep only columns that exist
vars_present <- intersect(vars_to_plot, names(skaters_clean))

if (length(vars_present) == 0) {
  stop("None of the requested variables exist in skaters_clean.")
}

df_long <- skaters_clean %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = all_of(vars_present),
    names_to = "variable",
    values_to = "value"
  )

ggplot(df_long, aes(x = value)) +
  geom_histogram(
    bins = 40,
    fill = "steelblue",
    color = "white",
    alpha = 0.7
  ) +
  facet_wrap(~ variable, scales = "free", ncol = 2) +
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of Key Performance Metrics",
    x = "Value",
    y = "Frequency"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()













Outliers can distort averages and influence statistical modeling.
We detect numeric outliers using the 1.5 × IQR rule.


Show / Hide Code
outlier_detection <- function(x) {
  q1 <- quantile(x, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE)
  q3 <- quantile(x, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)
  iqr <- q3 - q1
  sum(x < (q1 - 1.5 * iqr) | x > (q3 + 1.5 * iqr), na.rm = TRUE)
}

outliers <- skaters_clean %>%
  select(where(is.numeric)) %>%
  summarise(across(everything(), outlier_detection))

kable(outliers, caption = "Number of Outliers Detected per Variable")

The dataset contains a wide range of performance metrics with varying spreads.
Some variables show skewness, requiring possible transformation.
Several variables contain notable outliers.
Correlation analysis suggests meaningful relationships that will guide predictive modeling.

This descriptive statistics section provides a foundation for deeper inferential analysis and aligns with the quantitative structure of academic data analytics research.

title: descriptive
text:
This section summarizes the key descriptive statistics of the NHL skater performance dataset. We compute central tendencies, variability, distribution patterns, and identify any outliers that may influence later modeling steps.

# Load data
skaters <- read.csv("D:/GMU homeworks/STAT515/final proj/skaters.csv")

# Convert numeric-looking character columns
skaters_clean <- skaters %>%
  mutate(across(where(is.character), ~ suppressWarnings(as.numeric(.))))

# Summary statistics for numeric variables
numeric_summary <- skaters_clean %>%
  select(where(is.numeric)) %>%
  summarise(across(everything(),
                   list(
                     mean = ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                     median = ~ median(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                     sd = ~ sd(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                     min = ~ min(.x, na.rm = TRUE),
                     max = ~ max(.x, na.rm = TRUE)
                   ),
                   .names = "{.col}_{.fn}"
  ))

Below we visualize distributions for important performance variables such as shifts, TOI, xGoalsForAfterShifts, and xGoalsAgainstAfterShifts.


Show / Hide Code
library(tidyr)


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.5.2


Show / Hide Code
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Desired variables
vars_to_plot <- c(
  "shifts",
  "toi",
  "xGoalsForAfterShifts",
  "xGoalsAgainstAfterShifts"
)

# Keep only columns that exist
vars_present <- intersect(vars_to_plot, names(skaters_clean))

if (length(vars_present) == 0) {
  stop("None of the requested variables exist in skaters_clean.")
}

df_long <- skaters_clean %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = all_of(vars_present),
    names_to = "variable",
    values_to = "value"
  )

ggplot(df_long, aes(x = value)) +
  geom_histogram(
    bins = 40,
    fill = "steelblue",
    color = "white",
    alpha = 0.7
  ) +
  facet_wrap(~ variable, scales = "free", ncol = 2) +
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of Key Performance Metrics",
    x = "Value",
    y = "Frequency"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()













Outliers can distort averages and influence statistical modeling.
We detect numeric outliers using the 1.5 × IQR rule.


Show / Hide Code
outlier_detection <- function(x) {
  q1 <- quantile(x, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE)
  q3 <- quantile(x, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)
  iqr <- q3 - q1
  sum(x < (q1 - 1.5 * iqr) | x > (q3 + 1.5 * iqr), na.rm = TRUE)
}

outliers <- skaters_clean %>%
  select(where(is.numeric)) %>%
  summarise(across(everything(), outlier_detection))

kable(outliers, caption = "Number of Outliers Detected per Variable")

The dataset contains a wide range of performance metrics with varying spreads.
Some variables show skewness, requiring possible transformation.
Several variables contain notable outliers.
Correlation analysis suggests meaningful relationships that will guide predictive modeling.

This descriptive statistics section provides a foundation for deeper inferential analysis and aligns with the quantitative structure of academic data analytics research.

title: NHL Skater Performance Analytics
text:
This website presents the full analysis of the STAT 515 Final Project, focused on advanced analytics for NHL skater performance using the dataset located at:
D:/GMU homeworks/STAT515/final proj/skaters.csv
This website contains:

Data exploration

Preprocessing steps

Visual analytics

Three research questions

Statistical and ML modeling

Results, interpretation, and conclusion





Understand and preprocess the NHL skater dataset.

Conduct exploratory and statistical analysis.

Address three predictive analytics research questions:

RQ1: Shift Efficiency (xGF − xGA per shift)

RQ2: Special Teams Versatility

RQ3: On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta


Build predictive models.

Interpret results and derive insights.





Use the sidebar navigation to explore full pages:

About the Dataset
Data
Preprocessing
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
Research Questions (RQ1, RQ2, RQ3)
Modeling
Results
Discussion & Conclusion
Appendix

title: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance
text:
How does a player’s shift-based expected goal efficiency relate to overall on-ice performance in the 2023–2024 NHL season?
This research question focuses on understanding whether players who generate more positive outcomes during their shifts—measured using expected goals—also demonstrate stronger overall performance. Shift-level metrics are particularly valuable in hockey analytics because they normalize performance by opportunity, allowing for fairer comparisons across players with varying ice time and roles.
crumbs: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance

title: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance
text:
How does a player’s shift-based expected goal efficiency relate to overall on-ice performance in the 2023–2024 NHL season?
This research question focuses on understanding whether players who generate more positive outcomes during their shifts—measured using expected goals—also demonstrate stronger overall performance. Shift-level metrics are particularly valuable in hockey analytics because they normalize performance by opportunity, allowing for fairer comparisons across players with varying ice time and roles.
crumbs: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance

title: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance
text:
2 Motivation and Context
In modern hockey analytics, traditional statistics such as goals and assists are often insufficient to fully capture a player’s impact. Advanced metrics like expected goals for (xGF) and expected goals against (xGA) provide a probabilistic assessment of scoring chances based on shot quality, location, and game context. When these metrics are evaluated after player shifts, they offer insight into how effectively a player contributes to offensive pressure while limiting defensive risk.
By analyzing expected goals on a per-shift basis, this study seeks to answer whether players who consistently finish shifts with a positive expected goal differential can be identified as more efficient or impactful contributors. Such insights are valuable for coaching decisions, player evaluation, and roster optimization.
crumbs: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance

title: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance
text:
3 Analytical Approach
To address this research question, aggregated player-level data from the NHL skaters dataset were used. For each player, the total expected goals for after shifts and expected goals against after shifts were combined with the total number of shifts played. These values were used to compute an average shift efficiency metric, defined as the difference between expected goals for and against, normalized by the number of shifts.
The analysis examines:

The overall distribution of average shift efficiency across players
Identification of players with particularly high or low efficiency values
General trends that suggest whether shift efficiency meaningfully differentiates player performance

All statistical computations and visualizations supporting these findings are presented in the detailed analysis page.
crumbs: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance

title: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance
text:
4 Summary of Findings
The results indicate that average shift efficiency varies substantially across players, suggesting meaningful differences in how effectively players contribute during their time on the ice. A subset of players consistently demonstrates positive shift efficiency, reflecting stronger offensive impact and/or defensive reliability during shifts. Conversely, players with negative efficiency values may be associated with greater defensive exposure or reduced offensive effectiveness.
These findings support the usefulness of shift-based expected goal metrics as an evaluative tool, complementing traditional performance statistics. While shift efficiency alone does not capture all dimensions of player value, it provides a concise and interpretable measure of per-opportunity impact.
crumbs: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance

title: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance
text:
5 Link to Detailed Analysis
The full statistical analysis, including data preparation, metric construction, tables, and visualizations, is presented in:
➡ RQ1 Detailed Analysis (rq1_details.qmd)
This page includes reproducible R code and graphical outputs that support the conclusions summarized above.
crumbs: RQ1 — Research Question 1: Shift Efficiency and Player Performance

title: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta
text:
The third research question focuses on identifying which performance metrics most effectively distinguish high-impact skaters from low-impact skaters. Unlike RQ1 and RQ2, which examined shift efficiency and workload patterns, this section adopts a comparative and multivariate perspective. The goal is to determine which statistical indicators provide the strongest separation between top-performing and bottom-performing players.
Understanding these differentiating metrics is valuable for player evaluation, roster construction, and strategic decision-making. By isolating the variables that matter most, analysts can move beyond raw counts and focus on efficiency-driven indicators.
crumbs: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta

title: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta

title: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta
text:
2.1 Defining High- and Low-Impact Skaters
To differentiate player impact levels, we construct a composite impact score based on expected goal contribution after shifts. This score reflects a player’s net influence on scoring chances.


Show / Hide Code
df_clean <- df_clean %>%
mutate(
net_xg = xGoalsForAfterShifts - xGoalsAgainstAfterShifts
)


Players are then divided into high-impact and low-impact groups using quartiles of the net expected goals distribution.


Show / Hide Code
quantiles <- quantile(df_clean$net_xg, probs = c(0.25, 0.75), na.rm = TRUE)

impact_df <- df_clean %>%
filter(!is.na(net_xg)) %>%
mutate(
impact_group = case_when(
net_xg >= quantiles[2] ~ "High Impact",
net_xg <= quantiles[1] ~ "Low Impact",
TRUE ~ NA_character_
)
) %>%
filter(!is.na(impact_group))
crumbs: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta

title: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta
text:
2.2 Comparing Performance Metrics
We compare key metrics between high-impact and low-impact skaters, focusing on workload, scoring contribution, and possession-related indicators.


Show / Hide Code
metrics <- c(
"shifts",
"xGoalsForAfterShifts",
"xGoalsAgainstAfterShifts",
"net_xg"
)

summary_table <- impact_df %>%
group_by(impact_group) %>%
summarise(across(all_of(metrics), ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE)))

kable(summary_table, digits = 3,
caption = "Average Performance Metrics by Impact Group")

title: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta
text:
2.3 Visualization of Group Differences
The following visualization highlights how key metrics differ between high-impact and low-impact skaters.


Show / Hide Code
impact_long <- impact_df %>%
select(impact_group, all_of(metrics)) %>%
pivot_longer(cols = -impact_group,
names_to = "metric",
values_to = "value")

ggplot(impact_long, aes(x = impact_group, y = value, fill = impact_group)) +
geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
facet_wrap(~ metric, scales = "free") +
labs(title = "Metric Distributions by Skater Impact Level",
x = "Impact Group",
y = "Value") +
theme_minimal() +
theme(legend.position = "none")
crumbs: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta

title: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta
text:
2.4 Interpretation
High-impact skaters consistently demonstrate higher values of expected goals for after shifts and substantially stronger net expected goal contributions. In contrast, low-impact skaters tend to allow more expected goals against, reducing their overall on-ice effectiveness.
Interestingly, the number of shifts alone does not fully explain impact. While high-impact players often log more shifts, efficiency-based metrics—particularly net expected goals—provide clearer differentiation. This reinforces the importance of advanced analytics over raw usage statistics.
crumbs: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta

title: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta
text:
2.5 Conclusion
This analysis shows that net expected goal contribution after shifts is the most powerful single metric for separating high- and low-impact skaters. Supporting metrics such as expected goals for and against further clarify player effectiveness, while workload indicators play a secondary role.
These findings complement RQ1 and RQ2 by shifting the focus from descriptive patterns to comparative performance evaluation, offering actionable insight for coaches, analysts, and front offices.
In the next section (rq3_details.qmd), we extend this analysis with deeper statistical testing and robustness checks.
crumbs: RQ3 — On-Ice vs Off-Ice Impact Delta

title: NHL Skater Performance Analytics
text:
1 1. Introduction
This section provides a detailed analysis for Research Question 1 (RQ1), which investigates how efficiently NHL skaters contribute to expected goals during their on-ice shifts. Shift-level performance is crucial in hockey analytics because it captures short, repeatable bursts of play that reflect a player’s immediate offensive and defensive impact.
We quantify efficiency using expected goals for and against after shifts, normalized by the number of shifts played. This allows fair comparison across players with different usage levels.

title: NHL Skater Performance Analytics
text:

2.1 2.1 Load Required Libraries

title: NHL Skater Performance Analytics
text:
3 3. Feature Engineering

3.1 3.1 Construct Shift Efficiency Metric
We define Average Shift Efficiency as:
[ = ]
This metric captures net expected goal contribution per shift.


Show / Hide Code
df <- df %>%
  mutate(
    shifts = as.numeric(shifts),
    xgf_shift = as.numeric(xGoalsForAfterShifts),
    xga_shift = as.numeric(xGoalsAgainstAfterShifts),
    avg_shift_eff = ifelse(
      is.na(shifts) | shifts <= 0,
      NA_real_,
      (xgf_shift - xga_shift) / shifts
    )
  )

title: NHL Skater Performance Analytics
text:
5 5. Interpretation
Players with high average shift efficiency contribute positively in short, repeatable segments of play, indicating strong two-way impact. Importantly, efficiency does not scale linearly with ice time, suggesting that role and deployment significantly influence performance.
These findings reinforce the value of shift-normalized metrics when comparing players across teams and usage levels.

title: NHL Skater Performance Analytics
text:
6 6. Conclusion
RQ1 demonstrates that expected-goal-based shift efficiency provides a nuanced and fair evaluation of player performance. This metric serves as a foundation for subsequent analyses that explore contextual factors such as zone starts, usage, and on-ice teammates in later research questions.

title: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact
text:
This section provides statistical validation and deeper analysis supporting Research Question 3. While rq3.qmd focused on defining and visualizing player impact groups, this page formally tests whether the observed differences between high-impact and low-impact skaters are statistically meaningful.
The goal is to move beyond descriptive analytics and demonstrate inferential rigor, which is essential for an academic final project.

title: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact
text:
4.2 Hypothesis Formulation
We test whether high-impact players truly outperform low-impact players in terms of the defined impact score.

Null Hypothesis (H₀): There is no difference in mean impact score between high-impact and low-impact players.
Alternative Hypothesis (H₁): High-impact players have a significantly higher mean impact score than low-impact players.
crumbs: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact

title: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact
text:
4.3 Independent Samples t-Test
Given the two independent groups, we apply a two-sample t-test.


Show / Hide Code
t_test <- t.test(
impact_score ~ impact_group,
data = df_groups,
alternative = "greater"
)

t_test

 0.003440634         Inf
sample estimates:
mean in group High Impact  mean in group Low Impact 
             0.0035921996             -0.0004024715 



4.3.1 Interpretation

A small p-value (p < 0.05) provides strong evidence against the null hypothesis.
This indicates that the difference in impact scores is statistically significant, not due to random variation.
crumbs: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact

title: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact
text:
4.4 Effect Size (Practical Significance)
Statistical significance alone is insufficient. We compute Cohen’s d to quantify the magnitude of the difference.
cohens_d <- cohens_d(impact_score ~ impact_group, data = df_groups) cohens_d

4.4.1 Effect Size Interpretation

Small effect: d ≈ 0.2
Medium effect: d ≈ 0.5
Large effect: d ≥ 0.8

A medium-to-large effect size suggests that impact group membership has practical relevance, not just statistical significance.
crumbs: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact

title: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact
text:
4.5 Distribution Comparison
Visualizing the distributions helps validate test assumptions and interpret results intuitively.


Show / Hide Code
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(df_groups, aes(x = impact_score, fill = impact_group)) +
geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +
labs(
title = "Impact Score Distributions by Player Group",
x = "Impact Score",
y = "Density",
fill = "Group"
) +
theme_minimal()









The limited overlap between distributions visually supports the statistical findings.
crumbs: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact

title: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact
text:
4.6 Robustness Check: Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test
Because hockey performance metrics may deviate from normality, we also conduct a non-parametric test.


Show / Hide Code
wilcox.test(
impact_score ~ impact_group,
data = df_groups,
alternative = "greater"
)



    Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction

data:  impact_score by impact_group
W = 3207711, p-value < 2.2e-16
alternative hypothesis: true location shift is greater than 0


Consistent conclusions across parametric and non-parametric tests strengthen confidence in the results.
crumbs: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact

title: RQ3 Details: Statistical Validation of Player Impact
text:
4.7 Key Findings

High-impact skaters significantly outperform low-impact skaters based on shift-adjusted expected goals.
The observed difference is statistically significant and practically meaningful.
Results are robust across multiple testing frameworks.
